That's very nice... but how do you handle the situations where you want your
tests to fail fast? Can this be specified in the constructor?

-----Original Message-----
From: Shane Celis [mailto:shane@...]
Sent: Monday, September 17, 2001 5:51 PM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] Proper use of TestReult


I put together the following page in response to this discussion.  It was a
feature I needed when I first started working with JUnit.

Multiple Failures in a Singular Test <
http://www.gnufoo.org/junit/index.html#failures >

There has been a lot of discussion on the JUnit mailing list about allowing
multiple failures in a test. Some people insist that with the right amount
of refactoring there should be no need to introduce this flexibility. I,
however, found this wasn't the case. This restriction hampered my testing,
as I had to reflect more upon the framework than my tests themselves. Being
forced to choose between having only one assert per test which provided more
information, rather than the more logical aggregations of asserts which
provided less information. 

The change isn't radical by any means. It simply allows your tests to have
multiple failures attributed to them. Which means if you're say comparing a
collection of values, you get a report back of all the elements that didn't
match, not just the first one that caused an AssertionFailureError to be
thrown. 

I've put together a patch < http://www.gnufoo.org/junit/junit3.7a.patch >
against the 3.7 sources that you can apply. Or you can simply use this
junit3.7a.jar < http://www.gnufoo.org/junit/junit3.7a.jar > (source is
included in the jar). 

The test I added to SimpleTest looks like this: 

    public void testMultipleFailures() {
        fail("failing once");
        fail("failing twice");
        fail("failing once, again");
    }

Running test runner presents the results as follows (stack traces have been
removed for sake of brevity): 

$ java -classpath junit3.7a.jar junit.textui.TestRunner
junit.samples.SimpleTest
.F.E.FF.FFF
Time: 0.034
There was 1 error:
1) testDivideByZero(junit.samples.SimpleTest)java.lang.ArithmeticException:
/ by zero
There were 3 failures:
1) testAdd(junit.samples.SimpleTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
2) testEquals(junit.samples.SimpleTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError:
Size expected:<12> but was:<13>
3) testEquals(junit.samples.SimpleTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError:
Capacity expected:<12.0> but was:<11.99>
4)
testMultipleFailures(junit.samples.SimpleTest)junit.framework.AssertionFaile
dError: failing once
5)
testMultipleFailures(junit.samples.SimpleTest)junit.framework.AssertionFaile
dError: failing twice
6)
testMultipleFailures(junit.samples.SimpleTest)junit.framework.AssertionFaile

FAILURES!!!
Tests run: 4,  Failures: 3,  Errors: 1


The Swing and AWT TestRunner should work fine as well. The only
inconsistency that this has introduced is the listing of failures may exceed
the number of failed tests displayed on the status line, which is slightly
confusing since they've typically had a one to one correspondence until now.

Subject: Re: [junit] Proper use of TestReult


On 14 Sep, Vladimir Bossicard wrote:
> One thing you have to understand is that when a assertion failed, the
> method is exited because an Error is thrown.  There is no way to avoid
> this unless you write your own JUnit app.  I don't think that it's what
> you want...
> 

Right.

> if you have 3 mendatory fields, you write 4 methods.  The first 3 test
> that you successfully see when fields are missing and the 4th to see if
> everything's fine when you have your 3 mendatory fields.  You have done
> quite the same thing (removing one field after another) but my approach is
> more simple.
> 
> Remember: "keep tests simple".  The more complicated the test code is, the
> more likely you introduce errors in the test code.  The goal of unit
> testing is not to debug your test code :-)
> 

My problem with the 4 tests approach is that if for some reason the public
API
for the tests change, I have to change n+1 test methods. Whereas if I
contain
everything in a single test (as I'm doing now) I only have to change it once
when the public API changes (and yes, it has happened).

> to implement the simpliest tests possible:
> 
> - use the setUp() method to create your data object
> - create 4 tests methods (in my example it's 4)
> - remove one single mendatory field at the beginning of each test method
> - call the fail() method to tell JUnit that something wrong happend
> 

I'm just trying to concentrate all that in one test because I find
Cut'n'Paste to be error prone. In our case, we test data that has 12 or 14
mandatory fields and 3 or 4 optional. Repeating the exact same code 18 times
screams REFACTORING! And to me a proper refactoring of such identical tests
is
to put it all in one method. I'm just looking for a friendly way to show 8
failures if 8 of the test cases fail. So far, the best I've come up with is
to create a string with all the names of the fields that have failed and
print
them in the fail() call. But it's not very appealing visually.
